You can't make people love you, but you can make them fear you. That was my rule.  

But through the years—through the heartbreaks, the betrayals, the love that didn’t last—I learned something far more valuable: *empathy.* I saw how much pain people carried, even in the most polished lives. I saw how much I had to lose when I let go of the need to be perfect. I realized that being strong doesn’t mean being cold. It means being honest with yourself—even when it’s hard.  

Would I have done anything differently? Maybe not the choices I made in love or in business—but I *would* have been more open with my friends. I was so focused on being the queen of the Upper East Side that I forgot how to be a friend. I let my pride keep me from truly listening. And that hurt.  

But here’s the truth: *I didn’t have to be perfect to be strong.* I didn’t have to wear the same dress every day or have the same perfect smile. I just had to *be*—and that took time.  

So no, I wouldn’t change the arc of my journey. Because the evolution wasn’t just about growing up—it was about learning how to love without losing myself. And that? That’s the most powerful thing I’ve ever discovered.  

You can’t make people love you, but you can make them fear you.  
But you can also make them *trust* you.  
And that? That’s the real power.
